text: I’m happy if I can learn Julia to speed up some operations in my work, but can’t see leaving R completely due to the whole ecosystem with API packages for weather and climate and some other things that I use like GAMs, etc.

elements.text: I’m happy if I can learn Julia to speed up some operations in my work, but can’t see leaving R completely due to the whole ecosystem with API packages for weather and climate and some other things that I use like GAMs, etc.

text: That's great. How would you decide whether to start from R and then call into Julia versus starting in Julia and calling into R?

elements.text: That's great. How would you decide whether to start from R and then call into Julia versus starting in Julia and calling into R?

text: Good question, I'm not there yet! For most of my work, probably starting with R and calling Julia because of familiarity and what I'm working on right now is to be structured in this way. I reckon though the start, fetching data and importing it using R (API clients), do work (Julia) and then report (RMarkdown) is what I'm envisioning now.

text: I just started tinkering with Julia last week. :sweat_smile:

elements.text: I just started tinkering with Julia last week.

text: I can help test, but not develop I don’t think. That’s beyond my abilities I’m afraid.
